CRUD With Laravel

January 17, 2016 | 4 Minute Read

Hello, Laravel

Ive very opinionated in the frameworks I like and use. Its more interesting to use plain old PHP objects rather then a cumbersome framework to me. For the past 5 months, we have been focused on using SOLID principles in our code at work. No framework, no packages. Just simple PHP objects in a clean code setting. And its awesome! Really makes you step back and think about what you are coding. You must be wondering then why Im going to talk about Laravel, the current king of the PHP frameworks. Its funny, I was pretty against Laravel for a while. A lot of the community members for Laravel tend to be extremely opinionated in their mindset. Nothing wrong, but I have a feeling some Laravel developers are specifically Laravel, and if you took that away, how would/could they write their application? And this is by no means an attack, just my opinion.

Last month, while in a car for 6 hours, I decided to grab a book off leanpub for the ride. I picked one on Laravel 5. Don't know why, maybe cause it was cheap? Probably the reason, sounds like me. As I was reading, things were clicking. Which finally made me sit down and see what Laravel can really do.

So without further adieu, lets build a simple blog with Laravel.

Setting up the environment

If you want to follow along, great if you are just getting started with Laravel, you will need to download:

  • VirtualBox
  • Vagrant

Why? Well, you can always do MAMP/WAMP/XAMPP and it'll work great. But with Vagrant, you get the added skill of working in the terminal and using commands in the shell.That translates well on to a resume and looking for a job. So take a minute and get those set up. When you are done, look at Scotch Vagrant Box. There are hundreds of vagrantfiles out there. Theres a great website, puphpet where you can configure all kinds of awesome things.

Simple set up, wherever you prefer your files to be, create a folder called "blog" or whatever. Inside of that folder, create a folder called "public". In the blog folder, paste in the Vagrantfile you got from box.scotch.io. Your folder should look like:

Next, you will want to open up your terminal and change directory (cd) into the blog directory like so:

Now run vagrant up. If its your first time running this, it will take a few minutes to download everything. Once it is done, you need to run

The next thing you should see is:

And so now we are successfully in our vagrant server! Now, lets get to the good stuff. CD into /var/www/public first and then lets install a fresh Laravel instance. We can do that in two ways, either through the Laravel installer or with Composer. Ill be honest, I prefer Composer, so lets run this:

Let it run through its thing, and you will see everyhting you are bringing into the instance to run Laravel.

Once it says its done, go to 192.168.33.10, and you should see the Laravel 5 Intro Page. Success?!

What do you want now?

So lets take a moment and see what we need? Well, if we want to do a simple CRUD Blog, we need a few things. A page to display our posts, a place for us to update our posts or write new ones, as well as delete ones. We also will want a table to store our posts.

So lets set up our tables first. For this to work, we are going to use the Laravel Migrations. Its an awesome Artisan tool that is packages with Laravel. So in your terminal, type
